Building an AI Sales Simulator That Thinks Like a PMM

Hyunsoo Shim is creating BattleCoach ‚Äî an agentic AI prototype that transforms static battlecards into dynamic competitive coaching.

By Chris O'Hara ¬∑ February 28, 2026 ¬∑ 8 min read

Hyunsoo Shim doesn't use AI to write emails faster. She's using it to redesign how we prepare sellers to win.

With a background in building executive communities like the CPO Think Tank and leading competitive field readiness initiatives, Soo has spent her career translating complex product portfolios into clear, differentiated value stories. Her latest experiment takes that expertise to a new level: BattleCoach ‚Äî an AI-powered competitive co-pilot and deal simulator for sellers.

But here's what makes Soo's project different from most AI experiments: she's not just building a tool. She's rethinking the entire model of how competitive intelligence gets delivered to the field.

The Mandate ‚Äî and the Problem

"Focus on conversion. Arm the field with updated messaging and scripts ‚Äî helping them script their customer meetings and ensuring they know our latest differentiated messaging."
‚Äî Etosha Thurman, CMO, F&SM

That's the directive. Clear enough. But when Soo looked at how competitive enablement actually worked in practice, she found a series of uncomfortable truths:

üö® The Reality Check

  • Field says they're not competitively enabled ‚Äî despite all the content we create
  • Content exists ‚Äî but it's static, not deal-specific
  • We only have portfolio-level battlecards (Ariba vs X) ‚Äî not solution-level guidance
  • No buyer-centric competitive positioning ‚Äî just feature comparisons
  • Sellers are recreating messaging in every deal ‚Äî reinventing the wheel constantly

And perhaps the most damning insight of all:

"Our competitive messaging often fails the logo swap test."

If you can swap your company's logo for a competitor's and the messaging still works, you don't have differentiation ‚Äî you have generic claims. Soo wanted to fix that.

The Vision: Crawl ‚Üí Walk ‚Üí Run

Rather than trying to build the perfect AI system from day one, Soo designed a phased approach that would build capability progressively ‚Äî starting with foundational work and evolving toward true agentic AI.

üü¢ Crawl

Build the Foundation

  • Identify top 3 buying scenarios
  • Define solution-level moats (pass logo swap test)
  • Create 9 scenario-based battlecards
  • Convert into field-ready scripts
  • Launch BattleCoach prototype
OUTPUT: Guided script generator
üü° Walk

Add Intelligence

  • Layer persona + industry modifiers
  • Connect to CRM signals
  • Trigger scripts based on objections heard
  • Add deal risk diagnostics
OUTPUT: Context-aware AI assistance
üî¥ Run

Agentic BattleCoach AI

  • AI reads deal notes and call transcripts
  • Detects risk signals
  • Recommends plays dynamically
  • Adapts scripts in real time
  • Flags deal drift and escalation needs
OUTPUT: Autonomous competitive co-pilot

The goal isn't just to move from static content ‚Üí to intelligent systems. It's to move from "hoping differentiation sticks" to "institutionalizing PMM intelligence into a scalable system."

The Prototype: BattleCoach in Action

Soo and her team kicked off a 3-day competitive hackathon to build the first working prototype. The goals were clear:

  1. Refine competitive positioning and differentiation across 3 flagship buying scenarios
  2. Convert them into field-ready scripts and talk tracks
  3. Build a working BattleCoach prototype together

What emerged was a prototype that treats AI as a structured reasoning engine ‚Äî not just a content generator. Let's walk through how it works.

Inside BattleCoach: The Complete Walkthrough

1

Start: Create a New Deal

2

Coach Mode: AI-Generated Competitive Plays

Let's break down what you're seeing in Coach Mode. For this deal ‚Äî Finalist stage, competing against Coupa, in Manufacturing ‚Äî BattleCoach generates three strategic plays:

üéØ Recommended Plays

‚úÖ Executive narrative + finalist meeting plan

Finalist conversations are won on executive confidence: risk, outcomes, adoption, and commercial clarity.

Coach says: Build a 30-min exec flow: outcomes ‚Üí proof ‚Üí rollout plan ‚Üí risk controls ‚Üí commercial path.

‚òê Pre-empt competitor 'last-mile' traps

Competitors try to win with UI demos or pricing anchors. You need guardrails.

Coach says: Agree on demo scoring rubric tied to criteria; ask for written scoring before pricing discussion.

‚úÖ Stop the UI-only conversation

Coupa thrives when the buyer equates 'easy UX' with 'enterprise success'. Shift to governance, adoption at scale, and rollout patterns.

Coach says: Use 'Ease matters ‚Äî and so does what happens at global scale. Can we score both UX and controls/governance against your criteria?'

The right panel auto-generates a complete Coach Pack ‚Äî including a 30-minute meeting plan, structured talk track with opening scripts, and next actions. All tailored to this specific deal context.

  • "Ariba UX is dated"

  • "Community intelligence = better sourcing decisions"

This isn't generic battlecard content. It's deal-specific competitive coaching ‚Äî the kind of guidance that used to require a PMM to personally review every deal.

‚úÖ The Shift in Enablement

  • Define buying-scenario based battlecards ‚Äî not portfolio-level comparisons
  • Sharpen solution-level differentiation and moats ‚Äî pass the logo swap test
  • Convert narratives into field-ready scripts ‚Äî not just messaging frameworks
  • Build a dynamic, AI-powered BattleCoach ‚Äî that adapts to each deal

Why This Matters Beyond SAP

What Soo is building represents a fundamental shift in how competitive intelligence could work. Instead of:

  • Sending decks to the field and hoping differentiation sticks
  • Relying on tribal knowledge from experienced reps
  • Having PMMs manually review every competitive deal

BattleCoach aims to deliver:

  • Rehearsal before executive conversations ‚Äî sellers can practice against simulated buyers
  • Repeatable competitive thinking ‚Äî not dependent on individual PMM availability
  • Faster confidence in deal strategy ‚Äî guidance in minutes, not days
  • Institutionalized PMM intelligence ‚Äî tribal knowledge becomes scalable systems

The Bigger Lesson

What makes Soo's approach remarkable isn't just the technology ‚Äî it's the reframe. She recognized that AI for PMM isn't about writing faster. It's about building new capabilities:

  • A simulation engine ‚Äî for realistic practice scenarios
  • A structured thinking partner ‚Äî for strategic reasoning
  • A system that captures institutional differentiation ‚Äî preserving tribal knowledge
  • A prototyping tool ‚Äî testing new enablement models before formal investment

What started as a 3-day hackathon prototype is now shaping how competitive excellence could become an embedded capability ‚Äî not just an asset repository.

Hyunsoo "Soo" Shim
